content: With a tank of regular unleaded selling for $2.26/gallon, you would have to drive nearly 65,000 miles before you would start to see the savings. Obama anticipates the plan, which also calls for reduced carbon dioxide emissions, will add $1,300 to the sticker price of vehicles. Is that a cost customers are willing to pay? More here: "http://www.digtriad.com/news/features/article.aspx?storyid=124431&catid=216" "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford
reply: With a tank of regular unleaded selling for $2.26/gallon, you would have to drive nearly 65,000 miles before you would start to see the savings. title: How much could better fuel economy cost you?

content: If it is going to take 65k miles to see savings at only 2.26, what about when it goes back up over 3 and 4 bucks? Is this really helping or just smoke screens. "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford

content: Absolutely, we should all drive 10 miles per gallon HUMMER’s cuz there’s really no math in driving a car that gets 40 miles per gallon.... "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
reply: Absolutely, we should all drive 10 miles per gallon HUMMER’s cuz there’s really no math in driving a car that gets 40 miles per gallon.... "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
title: How much could better fuel economy cost you?

content: quote: Originally posted by Anbar7: If it is going to take 65k miles to see savings at only 2.26, what about when it goes back up over 3 and 4 bucks? Is this really helping or just smoke screens. I dunno. I drive 10K a year, and at the above rate that costs me $1125 a year. If I was getting forty MPG, I would pay $550 a year, meaning that after 30K I would break even on costs, and the rest would be gravy. Now my car gets 20MPG, if I was driving one of those 15MPG SUV's, my savings would occur a lot sooner. And mind you, this would also be one way of holding down future increases in the cost of gasoline, which doesn't even figure into the equation. Might as well wish for the return of the "Good Old Days," where a big Caddy got 3MPG... Dave
quote: Originally posted by Anbar7: If it is going to take 65k miles to see savings at only 2.26, what about when it goes back up over 3 and 4 bucks? Is this really helping or just smoke screens.

content: quote: Originally posted by Anbar7: With a tank of regular unleaded selling for $2.26/gallon, you would have to drive nearly 65,000 miles before you would start to see the savings. Obama anticipates the plan, which also calls for reduced carbon dioxide emissions, will add $1,300 to the sticker price of vehicles. Is that a cost customers are willing to pay? More here: "http://www.digtriad.com/news/features/article.aspx?storyid=124431&catid=216" You are leaving out the FACT that the reason the gas went down to $2.26 is that WORLD demand fell due to the recession. Before anyone bring up the tax issue what is being proposed by some is shifting payment for road infrastructure from part fuel and road use tax and part (majority at Fed and I think also at state) general fund tax revenue to a larger percent from usage taxes and fees (fuel, road tax, etc.) so USERS pay more of the cost for transportation infrastructure. Plus the car I used in the 90's got almost 40MPG highway so it is doable. The inside room was close to that of a midsize and better than some midsizes at the time, I do not fit in many cars because my torso is the same length as the avg for a 6'6" to 6'7" man.

Before anyone bring up the tax issue what is being proposed by some is shifting payment for road infrastructure from part fuel and road use tax and part (majority at Fed and I think also at state) general fund tax revenue to a larger percent from usage taxes and fees (fuel, road tax, etc.) so USERS pay more of the cost for transportation infrastructure. Plus the car I used in the 90's got almost 40MPG highway so it is doable.
